free_txt: Compiled by S.H.

bib_record.title: Beta-decay half-lives of 134,134mSb and their isomeric yield ratio produced by the spontaneous fission of 252Cf

free_txt: The Californium Rare Isotope Breeder
Upgrade facility at Argonne National Laboratory was
used to deliver pure beams of mass-separated ions 134,
134mSb from the spontaneous fission of approx. 1.7-Ci
252Cf source at the CARIBU facility. A radio frequency
quadrupole RFQ buncher containing residual helium gas
was used to accumulate, cool, and bunch the beam with
a timing of 100 ms between bunches.
Ratio of the yield of the high-spin to low-spin
nuclear states of 134mSb to 134Sb was determined from
beta singles build-up and decay for both the short
and long tape cycles, taking into account the
relative efficiency for beta detection for each
species, as well as the decay losses incurred during
the transport time
The correction for decay prior to measurement was made.
This included 30 ms extraction time of the fission
products from the CARIBU source to the buncher followed
by the 100 ms buncher cycle. These corrections shift
the yield ratio by 8%.
Decay station consisted equiped with a plastic
scintillation detector for detection of beta rays
with diameter of 10 cm and length of 10 cm. The
detector has a 6-mm diameter well bored in it to
allow the beam to implant on a 35-mm-wide
aluminized-mylar tape which passes through a slot in
the middle of the detector oriented at 90deg to the
beam direction.
Array of five high-purity germanium clover
detectors was used mainly to determine half-lifes of
134Sb nuclei.
The Californium Rare Isotope Breeder
Upgrade facility at Argonne National Laboratory was
used to deliver pure beams of mass-separated ions 134,
134mSb from the spontaneous fission of approx. 1.7-Ci
252Cf source at the CARIBU facility. A radio frequency
quadrupole RFQ buncher containing residual helium gas
was used to accumulate, cool, and bunch the beam with
a timing of 100 ms between bunches.
134mSb,134Sb ions were produced from the spontaneous
fission of a 1.7-Ci 252Cf source at the CARIBU
facility. The 252Cf fission fragments were
thermalized using a large helium-filled gas catcher
and extracted as a continuous low-energy beam of
singly charged ions from the nozzle of this device
using a combination of gas flow and electric fields.
The beam was sent through an isobar separator operated
with a mass resolution of M/dM=15000 to
isolate 134,134mSb.
Measured by authors
Measured by authors
Source of uncertainties not described
Data taken from tab.2 of the reference
